1.question: The fact that companies often falter because the people who start the firms can't adjust quickly enough to their new roles and because the firm lacks a "track record" with outside buyers and sellers, is referred to as the

2.question: Savanna Combs opened a clothing boutique two years ago. Unfortunately, the boutique failed after 18 months. Savanna attributes the failure of her boutique to the fact that her employees couldn't adjust quickly enough to their new roles and that her boutique lacked a "track record" with outside buyers and sellers, which made it difficult to form partnerships and make sales. Savanna suffered from what research calls the

3.question: The high failure rate among new ventures is due, in part, to the liability of newness, which refers to the fact that new companies often falter because

options.A: they are underfunded and the founders of the firms don't move quickly enough to put together boards of directors and boards of advisors that can provide them direction and advice
options.B: the founders of the firms underestimate the complexities involved with starting a new business and the firms lack a "track record" with outside buyers and sellers
options.C: the people who start the firms can't adjust quickly enough to their new roles and the firms lack a "track record" with outside buyers and sellers
options.D: the people who start the firms can't adjust quickly enough to their new roles and they are underfunded
options.E: the founders of the firms underestimate the complexities involved with starting a new business and they don't move quickly enough to establish business partnerships

4.question: Sam Atkinson, a new entrepreneur who had just launched his venture, joined an entrepreneurship boot camp. Sam's goal in joining the boot camp was to overcome the liability of

5.question: The term "liability of newness" refers to the fact that companies often falter because the people who start the firms can't adjust quickly enough to their new roles and because the firms lack "track records" with outside buyers and suppliers.

6.question: Kathy Denver is preparing to launch a home security firm. The team of people that will launch Kathy's firm are as follows: Kathy (CEO), Trevor (VP-Finance), Shelia (VP-Sales), a four-person Board of Directors, a five-person Board of Advisors, and Kathy's primary investor, who will assume an advisory role. The group of people that will launch Kathy's firm is called its

7.question: Which of the following was NOT identified in the textbook as an element of a new venture team?

8.question: According to the textbook, studies show that more than one individual starts ______ percent of all new firms.

9.question: Which of the following statements is untrue regarding founding teams?

options.A: The members of heterogeneous teams are diverse in terms of their abilities and experiences.
options.B: The members of homogenous teams are very similar in terms of their abilities and experiences.
options.C: Teams that have worked together before have an edge.
options.D: Studies show that more than one individual starts 50 to 70 percent of all new firms.
options.E: It is generally believed that new ventures started by an individual have an advantage over new ventures started by a team.

10.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding founding teams?

options.A: The members of heterogeneous teams are diverse in terms of their abilities and experiences.
options.B: Teams that are working together for the first time have an advantage over teams that have worked together before.
options.C: The psychological support that cofounders of a new business can offer one another is an important element of a firm's success.
options.D: The members of homogeneous teams are very similar in terms of their abilities and experiences.
options.E: Studies show that more than one individual starts 50 to 70 percent of all new teams.

11.question: The members of heterogeneous teams are

options.A: diverse in terms of their abilities and experiences
options.B: diverse in terms of their abilities, but very similar in terms of their experiences
options.C: similar in terms of their abilities and experiences
options.D: diverse in terms of their experiences, but very similar in terms of their abilities
options.E: sometimes diverse in terms of their abilities and experiences and sometimes similar along the same dimensions

12.question: The members of homogeneous teams are ______ in terms of their ______.

options.B: diverse; abilities, but very similar in terms of their experiences
options.D: diverse; experiences, but very similar in terms of their abilities
options.E: sometimes diverse; abilities and experiences and sometimes similar along the same dimensions

13.question: According to the textbook, which of the following statements is inaccurate regarding the size and composition of the founding team of a firm?

options.A: There is no relationship between a founding team's size and its effectiveness.
options.B: A founding team larger than four people is typically too large to be practical.
options.C: The members of a homogeneous founding team are similar in terms of their abilities and experiences.
options.D: The members of a heterogeneous founding team are diverse in terms of their abilities and experiences.
options.E: A founding team can be too big, causing communication problems and increasing potential for conflict.

14.question: According to the textbook, prior entrepreneurial experience

options.A: is one of the poorest predictors of future entrepreneurial performance
options.B: is one of the most consistent predictors of future entrepreneurial performance for entrepreneurs under 50 years of age, but not for entrepreneurs over 50 years of age
options.C: is one of the most consistent predictors of future entrepreneurial performance
options.D: is one of the most consistent predictors of future entrepreneurial performance in service firms, but not in manufacturing firms
options.E: has no relationship to future entrepreneurial performance

15.question: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the attributes of the founder(s) of a firm?

options.A: Evidence suggests that important entrepreneurial skills are enhanced through higher education.
options.B: Founders with prior entrepreneurial experience are more likely to avoid costly mistakes.
options.C: Founders with experience in the same industry as their new ventures will typically have "blinders" on and are typically not as effective as founders new to the industry.
options.D: Founders with broad social and professional networks have an advantage.
options.E: New ventures that are started by a team rather than an individual have an advantage.

16.question: Which of the following qualities was NOT identified in the textbook as a preferred attribute of the founder(s) of a firm?

options.D: Prior experience working in a government or university position

17.question: The What Went Wrong feature in Chapter 9 focuses on Devver, a 2008 startup that helped software developers use cloud-based services to "test" their code in an expedient manner. According to the feature, one of the primary reasons Devver failed was

options.A: it lacked a cofounder who loved the business side of running a startup
options.C: it didn't build a robust partnership network
options.D: it didn't solicit advice from attorneys, bankers or business consultants
options.E: it didn't have a Board of Advisors

18.question: The process of building and maintaining relationships with people whose interests are similar or whose relationship could bring advantages to the firm is called

19.question: Sam Simpson is a four-time business owner. One thing that has served Sam well throughout his entrepreneurial career is his ability to build and maintain relationships with people whose interests are similar or whose relationships could bring advantages to his new ventures. According to the textbook, Sam is a good

20.question: A(n) ______ is a chart that depicts the most important skills that are needed in a new venture and where skills gaps exist.

21.question: Jason Andersen just finished writing a business plan for a new type of office supply store. One thing Jason included in the "Management Team & Company Structure" section of his business plan is a chart that depicts the most important skills that are needed for his business and where skills gaps exist. Jason included a(n) ______ in his business plan.

22.question: A skills profile is a chart that depicts the

options.A: preferable skills and abilities of the members of a firm's board of advisors
options.B: preferable skills and abilities of the members of a firm's board of directors
options.C: most important skills that are needed in a business startup and where skills gaps exist
options.D: skills and abilities that will be needed for a firm to maintain an aggressive growth strategy
options.E: skills of a company's customers and how those skills impact the products and services a company provides

23.question: The Savvy Entrepreneurial Firm feature in Chapter 9 focuses on "lifehacks." According to the feature, a "lifehack" refers to any trick, shortcut, ability, or novelty method that increases a person's ______, efficiency, and effectiveness in both his or her personal life and career.

24.question: A(n) ______ is a person who works for a business as an apprentice or trainee for the purpose of obtaining actual experience.

25.question: A(n) ______ is a person who is in business for themselves, works on their own time with their own tools and equipment, and performs services for a number of different clients.

27.question: A board of directors is typically made up of both ______ and ______ directors.

28.question: In the context of boards of directors, a(n) ______ director is a person who is also an officer of the firm.

29.question: In the context of boards of directors, a(n) ______ director is someone who is not employed by the firm.

30.question: James Williams is the Chief Operating Officer of a startup in the health food industry. He is also a member of his firm's board of directors. In board of directors terminology, James is a(n) ______ director.

31.question: Adam Miller is a general partner in a venture capital firm that just funded Gold Coast Software, a software firm in Santa Barbara, California. Gold Coast Software is incorporated, and Adam has taken a seat on the firm's board of directors. In board of directors terminology, Keith is a(n) ______ director.

32.question: A board of directors' three formal responsibilities are to

options.A: periodically update the firm's business plan, declare dividends, and write the firm's marketing plan
options.B: appoint the officers of the firm, declare dividends, and oversee the affairs of the corporation
options.C: write the firm's strategic plan, declare dividends, and conduct the annual meeting
options.D: appoint the officers of the firm, conduct the annual meeting, and submit the firm's annual report to the Securities & Exchange Commission
options.E: provide funding to the firm, write the firm's strategic plan, and submit the firm's annual report to the Securities & Exchange Commission

33.question: A board of directors' three formal responsibilities are to appoint the officers of the firm, oversee the affairs of the corporation, and

options.C: submit the firm's annual report to the stockholders

34.question: A board of directors' three formal responsibilities are to appoint the officers of the firm, declare dividends, and

options.D: represent the firm in public relations activities
options.E: oversee the affairs of the corporation

35.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding boards of directors?

options.A: If a new venture organizes as a corporation, it is not legally required to have a board of directors, but it is strongly recommended.
options.B: A board is typically made up of both inside and outside directors.
options.C: The board is responsible for declaring dividends.
options.D: Most boards meet formally three or four times a year.
options.E: The boards for publicly-traded companies are required by law to have audit and compensation committees.

36.question: According to the textbook, although a board of directors has formal governance responsibilities, its most useful role is to

options.A: provide guidance and support to the firm's managers
options.B: submit papers on behalf of the firm to the SEC
options.C: represent the firm in public relations activities

37.question: Liz Zackery just launched a firm in the sporting goods industry. On the day the company was launched, Liz issued a press release, indicating that the vice president of New Balance, a highly respected athletic shoe and sports apparel company, had agreed to serve on her board of directors. Liz knows that such a high quality appointment will send an important message to her potential clientele. This phenomenon is referred to as

38.question: Melissa Jones just launched a firm in the wireless communications industry. Shortly after the company was launched, Melissa announced that a prominent Silicon Valley venture capitalist had agreed to serve on her board of directors. Melissa knows that such a high quality appointment will send an important message to her potential business partners and clientele. This phenomenon is referred to as

39.question: Which of the following was NOT identified in the textbook as an attribute of an effective board of directors?

options.A: Homogeneous set of experiences and talents
options.C: Ability and willingness to stand up to the CEO and top managers of the firm

40.question: Which of the following was NOT identified in the textbook as an attribute of an effective board member?

options.D: Ability and willingness to mentor the CEO and the top managers of the firm

41.question: A new venture team is the group of founders, key employees, and advisors that move a new venture from an idea to a fully functioning firm.

42.question: Studies show that more than one individual starts 50 to 70 percent of all new firms.

43.question: It is generally believed that new ventures started by an individual have an advantage over those started by a team.

44.question: Founding teams that have worked together before, as opposed to teams that are working together for the first time, have an edge.

45.question: Homogeneous teams are diverse in terms of their abilities and experiences.

46.question: Prior entrepreneurial experience, relevant industry experience, and networking are attributes that strengthen the chances of a founder's success.

47.question: Prior entrepreneurial experience is a poor predictor of future entrepreneurial performance.

48.question: Networking is building and maintaining relationships with people whose interests are similar or whose relationship could bring advantages to a firm.

49.question: A skills profile is a chart that depicts the most important skills that are needed and where skills gaps exist.

50.question: A virtual assistant is a freelancer who provides administrative, technical, or creative assistance to clients remotely from a home office.

57.question: Kelly Andersen founded a technology consulting firm several years ago. Her firm has grown rapidly and is financially successful. One thing that Kelly attributes her success to is that early on she assembled a panel of experts who provided her ongoing direction and advice about her business. What Kelly created is called a(n)

58.question: Which of the following statements about advisory boards is incorrect?

options.A: The fact that a corporation has a board of directors does not preclude it from establishing one or more advisory boards.
options.B: An advisory board can be established for general purposes or can be set up to address a specific issue or need.
options.C: Similar to a board of directors, an advisory board has legal responsibility for the firm in certain areas.
options.D: An advisory board is a panel of experts who are asked by a firm's managers to provide counsel and advice on an ongoing basis.
options.E: A growing number of startups are forming advisory boards.

59.question: Which of the following statements about advisory boards is incorrect?

options.A: If a firm has a board of directors, it is not permitted to have an advisory board.
options.B: Many people are more willing to serve on a company's board of advisors than its board of directors because it requires less time and there is no potential legal liability involved.
options.C: Most boards of advisers have between 5 and 15 members.
options.D: A growing number of startups are forming advisory boards.
options.E: An advisory board can be established for general purposes or can be set up to address a specific issue or need.

60.question: According to the textbook, most boards of advisers have between ______ and ______ members.

61.question: An advisory board is a panel of experts who are asked by a firm's managers to provide counsel and advice on an ongoing basis.

62.question: Similar to a board of directors, an advisory board possesses legal responsibility for the firm.

63.question: An advisory board can be established for general purposes or can be set up to address a specific need.

64.question: The fact that a corporation has a board of directors precludes it from having a board of advisors.

65.question: Most boards of advisors have between 3 and 5 members.

66.question: More people are willing to serve on a company's board of directors than on its board of advisors.

67.question: A business ______ is an individual who gives professional or expert advice, on a volunteer or fee basis.

68.question: Which of the following is incorrect regarding the typical role of consultants in business startups?

options.B: International consulting firms (e.g., Accenture and Bearing Point) are financially beyond the reach of most small firms.
options.C: Consultants fall into two categoriesâ€”paid consultants and consultants who are made available for free.
options.E: Help manage the day-to-day activities of the firm
